awd_titl_txt: Increasing ATE Career Placement for Students with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD): Identification and Dissemination of Best Practices
awd_abstract_narration:
According to the U.S. Center for Disease Control (CDC), the national prevalence of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) increased by 119.4 % from 1 in 150 (in 2000) to 1 in 68 (in 2010). The factors contributing to the increased prevalence of ASD include heightened public awareness, improved screening, changes in the diagnostic specification, and, notably, improved ability to recognize and diagnose higher-functioning individuals with ASD who may have been overlooked in the past. Evidence suggests that these individuals, sometimes referred to as having high-functioning ASD, may be the fastest growing sector of the autism population. The implications for institutions of higher education and for employers is far-reaching. In addition to improved diagnosis, the success of interventions and efforts to include students with ASD in mainstream activities has contributed to increased rates of college attendance. The number of students entering college with high-functioning autism spectrum disorders is expected to increase in coming years, and data reveal an enrollment rate of students with ASD at community colleges at more than twice that of four-year colleges.

This project will produce a series of video-based educational materials for the professional development of educators and employers. The overarching focus is to: 1) build awareness of academic and employer-based STEM programs that promote the college and workplace based success of individuals with ASD and, 2) to promote existing "Best Practices" to an expanded community of educational institutions, students with ASD and their families, and employers. The videos will showcase applied best practices across multiple STEM disciplines and specifically in technician preparation programs in advanced technological education. Pellet Productions will first perform an analysis of the current landscape of academic- and employer-based supports for individuals with ASD, and then produce a series of recruitment and professional development videos including: six student profiles, three ATE and STEM videos for families, and one ATE and ASD overview video for general audiences and a long form documentary-style best practices video that will form the basis for a professional development course to be offered via an online format. An e-Book will be produced to both accompany the course and serve as a stand-alone guide to best practice implementation. The primary audiences include: ATE faculty, student affairs personnel, corporate sector human resource personnel and supervisors, and students with ASD and their families to help guide their college and career decision process.

por.por_cntn:
Layered within the need to increase the awareness of pathways to skilled technician education is the need to focus efforts on improving resources and transition pathways specifically for autistic (ASD) individuals interested in further education and careers in STEM. While ASD individuals have the capacity to become productive and contributing members of the US technical workforce, autistic individuals remain under-enrolled, underserved and underrepresented in STEM education and STEM careers. Data shows further that autistic individuals who are successful at obtaining employment are often underemployed and in capacities which do not utilize their unique capabilities. The disconnect experienced by autistic learners during the beginning of post-secondary education, and the lack of resources focused specifically on the needs of autistic learners, often leads to withdrawal from educational programs. The Stairway to STEM Project was designed to understand the issues faced by autistic learners transitioning from high school to STEM educational programs in college, and the goal of this Project was to provide a resource to highlight those difficulties and offer guidance and practical advice. This was done utilizing a one of its kind model – creation of an online resource for which the input and content was primarily provided by and included perspectives directly from autistic individuals with first-hand experience facing these issues, obstacles and difficulties, who served as the Project’s subject matter experts because they could speak directly to other autistic individuals on how to navigate and overcome these issues.

 

The Stairway to STEM (STS) Project  focused on the following goals:  1. creation of  an online resource to assist Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) students interested in STEM and technician education as they transitioned from high school to post-secondary education; 2. establishing an online network and community of support for autistic students, family members, educators and others committed to ASD student success; 3. sharing educational knowledge, tools and best practices with college instructors, and support staff, such as high school transition counselors, to support ASD student transition, college success, and workforce preparedness; and 4. to host live college-transition events where ASD STEM students could prepare for college expectations, network and connect with other ASD families.

 

The STS project achieved these goals with the creation of the Stairway to STEM website, www.stairwaytostem.org, which includes a team of content creators and editorial board which created consistent, relevant, and high-quality content to attract and assist autistic users, create opportunities for STS contributors to speak to issues, difficulties, and obstacles, and provide interactive experiences in order to grow in influence among the autistic community. STS saw the consistent growth of its community of users and contributors. The Project had a broader impact on the educational and cultural communities, including the engagement of institutions such as Bellevue College, Tufts University, and SXSW EDU, which more broadly applied STS as a resource not only for autistic students but also educators and others supporting autistic students. In addition, the Project outcomes included the hosting of live events and virtual events which included educators, autistic students and others, focusing on making STEM education accessible to autistic learners, and afforded networking opportunities to those who attended.

 

The project includes the publication of three eBooks, and STS content is freely available and downloadable for use by autistic individuals, educators, and others in the autistic community providing support to autistic individuals. The STS website will remain an online resource for autistic learners, educators and the autistic community and continue to serve the goals of highlighting issues faced during transition from high-school to STEM, but also assist with reducing the barriers faced by autistic learners transitioning from high school to post-secondary education in STEM, and ultimately work toward the greater goals of increasing technician education by increasing the number of autistic individuals in STEM education and career pathways. In addition to being a resource for autistic individuals, STS serves as a resource for use by educators, counselors, families and others supporting autistic learners who are transitioning from high school to college in STEM education, and offers the broader impact of providing best practices in handling the issues and obstacles faced by autistic learners to assist them with successful completion of STEM education and ultimately employment in technician careers.
